Unemployment in Insured Industries.The latest date for which unemployment figures by industries are available is the 26th July, 1926, at which date the percentage unemployed in Great Britain and Northern Ireland was 14"6, as compared with 14'7 at the 21st June, 1926, with 11'2 at the 27th July, 1925, and with 9"6 at the 28th July, 1924. The past month has witnessed very little improvement of any importance in the general industrial position. Employment in most of the principal industries continued to be adversely affected by the coal-mining dispute. The large increase of over 18,000 in unemployment in the Cotton Industry is in general attributed to an increasing shortage of fuel supplies. The depression in this industry is especially acute in the principal weaving centres where alternate week working appears to be more or less the general rule. Attention is also directed to the increase of 15 per cent, in the unemployment in the Jute Industry during the last month, bringing the total percentage of unemployment in this highly localised industry on the 26th July to the deplorable figure of 56"2 per cent. The position in the Iron and Steel Industry and in Constructional Engineering was also somewhat more unsatisfactory. The increased unemployment in the Tailoring Industry is largely of a seasonal nature.In the group of industries comprised under the term " General Engineering," there has been a welcome improvement during the month. The reopening of a number of works which had been closed during June has also resulted in a reduction in unemployment in the Tinplate Industry. Compared with last month the position in the "Woollen and Worsted Industries, particularly in the former, is much more satisfactory.(D.) Latest Figures.The latest figures of unemployment published are those for the 9th August, giving the total number on the registers as 1,594,169. This is a decrease over the position on the 26th July amounting to 11,251, but an increase over a year ago of 396,538. The preliminary figure for the 16th August is 1,580,500, showing a decrease in one week of 13,669.ARTHUR STEEL-MAITLAND.Ministry of Labour,August 23, 1926.
